I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale  
   
1.  The Government of Pakistan (the Government) has set itself an ambitious target of 
creating 10 million jobs over five years, with a special focus on skill-building through technical and 
vocational education and training (TVET) in its first term. Achieving this target will require much 
better performance from the TVET sector. The scale of improvement required can be seen from 
the Global Competitiveness Report 2018, which showed that Pakistan ranked 125th overall for 
skills – with individual rankings of 90th for the quality of vocational training, 51st for the skillset of 
graduates, and 63rd for ease of finding skilled employees.1  
 
2.  Since the passage of the 18th Constitutional Amendment in 2010, provincial governments 
in Pakistan are responsible for delivering, funding and regulating TVET. In Punjab, the Industries, 
Commerce and Investment Department (ICID) has overall responsibility for the TVET sector, 
although many departments and agencies are involved in the sector. There are two principal 
public TVET providers in Punjab: the Technical Education and Vocational Training Authority 
(TEVTA) has some 400 institutes, while the Punjab Vocational Training Council (PVTC) has some 
270 institutes. TEVTA and PVTC are government funded. TEVTA is financed through ICID, while 
PVTC is funded through the Zakat and Ushr Department and the Planning and Development 
Department. Other TVET institutes include public providers operated by other governments 
departments and agencies, and a large private sector. TEVTA and PVTC also operate TVET 
teacher training centers. The structure of the TVET sector in Punjab is set out in Appendix 4.  
 
3.  The size of the TVET sector in Punjab dwarfs that in other provinces. In 2017, there were 
some 1,600 TVET institutes and 238,000 TVET enrolments in Punjab, representing 46.0% of all 
TVET institutes and 56.8% of all TVET enrolments in Pakistan. By comparison, Sindh had only 
17.0% of TVET institutes and 18.1% of TVET enrolments in Pakistan in 2017.2 The labor market 
in Punjab is characterized by low levels of skills, low female participation and a large informal 
sector.3 Women’s labor force participation is around one-third that of men. There is substantial 
occupational segregation, with females more likely to work in traditional jobs such as dressmakers 
and beauticians.4 Over 60% of the Pakistan population is under 25 and youth have low levels of 
education and little exposure to TVET. The unemployment rate for youth is high.5 The TVET 
sector’s challenges limit its ability to support competitiveness and inclusive economic growth 
through the supply of skilled workers. These challenges include:  
 
•  Quality and relevance of TVET. This is due to several factors, including outdated training 
methods, assessment techniques, curricula, and equipment; shortages of trained and 
qualified  TVET  instructors;  limited  linkages  between  the  TVET  sector  and  industry, 
including limited private sector participation in curriculum development; limited scope for 
on-the-job training for trainees; and limited private sector delivery of TVET.   
 
•  Participation in TVET. TVET trainees represent only 4−5% of the population aged 16−20 
years in Punjab. This is due to lack of TVET provision in some areas, low government and 
private sector spending on TVET, low female labor force participation rates, and education

requirements for accessing TVET. TVET participation is particularly limited for women and 
people in rural areas. In 2016/17, females made up 22.8% of enrolments and 24% of 
teachers at TEVTA institutes. They made up 48% of enrolments and 46% of teachers in 
PVTC institutes in 2017.6 Women in TVET usually enroll in traditional female courses, with 
little encouragement to enter male-dominated programs. The poor quality and relevance 
of TVET in Punjab also constrains TVET demand as potential trainees see little benefit 
from TVET in terms of higher future incomes or increased job opportunities.  
 
•  TVET policy and institutional framework. This includes the absence of an agency with 
overall responsibility for the planning, governance, regulation, quality assurance and 
financing of TVET in the province and fragmented responsibility for quality assurance. The 
skills  development  system  is  fragmented  and  lacks  the  mechanisms  to  deliver  a 
coordinated strategy, given the multiple funding streams and quality assurance agencies. 
There is a lack of systemic information collection and there is no centralized database on 
the TVET sector. The capacity of TVET institute management is also of concern.7  
 
4.  Improving  the  performance  of  the  TVET  sector  in  Punjab  can  help  lift  Pakistan’s 
development prospects given that it is the country’s most populous province; its economic 
powerhouse, and has several industrial centers including Lahore, Faisalabad, Sialkot, Multan, 
and Rawalpindi. Improved skills development was central to the Government of Punjab’s (GoPb) 
Punjab Growth Strategy 2018. The GoPb is also developing industrial clusters and supporting 
their further integration into global value chains. This initiative seeks to create an enabling 
environment for industrial growth and prosperity, improve the quality of life through economic 
uplift, upgrade technology, and enhance productivity, quality and profitability of local industries.8  
 
5.  Weaknesses in the TVET sector have led to a serious shortage of skilled workers in 
Punjab, which constrains economic growth and adversely affects the performance of industry. 
According to one survey, 60% of firms said that the TVET system did not produce enough people 
with the skills required by employers, and more than 50% of firms said that the TVET system did 
not produce enough people with up-to-date knowledge of methods, materials and technology.9 A 
survey  of  Lahore-based  manufacturers  identified  inadequately  trained  workers  as  a  key 
impediment  to  industrial  performance.  While  skill  shortages  affected  both  large  and 
small/medium enterprises, the impact was greater on the latter.10 Improving TVET can help 
close  the  skills  gap,  reduce  unemployment,  increase  productivity,  lift  competitiveness  and 
promote foreign direct investment.11,12,13

II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
6.  The transaction technical assistance (TRTA)14 will support project preparation and is 
justified given the scope of project activities and the specialized nature of skills required in areas 
such as the design of centers of excellence, public-private partnerships, and reform of institutional 
frameworks. The TRTA will provide technical inputs and assessments. The project is aligned with 
the ADB’s country partnership strategy 2015–2019 for Pakistan, which supports more inclusive 
access to jobs and economic opportunities.     
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
 
7.  The TRTA has three outputs:  
 
•  Output 1. Detailed project design developed. This output will develop the technical 
design parameters and detailed costings for the three project outputs, including: (i) design 
of  the  project,  including  centers  of  excellence,  PPP  programs,  work-based  training 
programs, and competency-based training and assessment; (ii) preparation of detailed 
project  costings,  including  civil  works,  consultancy,  capacity  building  and  project 
implementation; (iii) preparation of a project design and monitoring framework, including 
specification of performance indicators and project activities; (iv) identification of sector 
capacity  building  requirements;  (v)  identification  of  project  TVET  institutes;  (vi) 
identification of priority economic sectors; (vii) initial architectural designs for project 
institutes,  as  required;  (viii)  development  of  the  project  procurement  plan;  and  (ix) 
specification of project implementation plan.  
 
•  Output 2. Project due diligence undertaken. This output will support project due 
diligence, including: (i) TVET sector assessment, (ii) environmental assessment, (iii) 
economic and financial analysis, (iv) gender, poverty and social analysis, (v) financial 
management assessment of the executing and implementing agencies, (vi) procurement 
capacity and financial management assessments of the executing and implementing 
agencies; (vii) procurement risk assessment and procurement classification; (viii) social 
safeguards assessments; and (ix) risk assessment and management plan.  
 
•  Output 3. Project processing and implementation startup facilitated. This will include 
assisting in the preparation of all documents required for project processing, including the: 
(i) Report and Recommendation of the President (RRP) and all RRP linked documents, 
(ii) the project administration manual; and (iii) project startup and implementation support, 
including establishment of the project implementation unit.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
8.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $0.88 million equivalent, of which $0.8 million will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-6).  The 
Government will provide in-kind assistance in the form of exemption from taxes and duties, office 
accommodation, and counterpart staff. The cost estimates and financing plan are listed in

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  ADB will administer the TRTA. ICID will be the executing agency, while the Technical 
Education and Vocational Training Authority (TEVTA) and the Punjab Vocational Training Council 
(PVTC) will be implementing partners. The Social Sector Division of the Central and West Asia 
Department will coordinate project preparation. The TRTA will be implemented from April 2019 to 
April 2021 to ensure effective project preparation and startup. Implementation will be coordinated 
with development partners through the Punjab Skills Advisory Forum. Disbursements will be 
made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as 
amended from time to time). Implementation arrangements are in Table 1.

11.  Consulting services. ADB will recruit individual consultants to implement the TRTA. 
Allocated consultant requirements are estimated at 18 person-months of international inputs and 
29 person-months of national inputs, of which 2 international person-months and 4 national 
person-months are unallocated and which may be used to recruit technical consultants and 
resource persons in areas such as TVET policy and programs, business startup and small 
business finance, private sector involvement, qualifications frameworks and competency-based 
training and assessment, and safeguards.  
 
12.  The project may also recruit a firm to identify the TVET institutes and priority sectors and 
occupations, identify sites to be upgraded and prepare the initial architectural designs for project 
institutes. Consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and the associated project administration instructions/technical 
assistance staff instructions. The schedule of consultant requirements for the TRTA is in Table 2.
